Introduction

Retinitis pigmentosa is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive retinal degeneration involving the photoreceptors (eg, rods, cones) and pigmented epithelium, leading to visual impairment and potential blindness.  It is one of the most common forms of inherited retinal dystrophies, affecting approximately 1 in 4,000 people worldwide.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Retinitis pigmentosa occurs due to progressive degeneration of retinal cells (eg, rods, cones) caused by mutations in genes responsible for maintaining their structure and function.  Because rods are highly metabolic, they degenerate first, followed by cones and cells within the pigmented epithelium.  As the pigmented epithelium degenerates, the cells release pigment that forms deposits in a characteristic bone-spicule pattern visible on retinal examination.  In addition, histopathological examination of the retina demonstrates thinning of the outer nuclear layer and loss of photoreceptor cells.



Retinitis pigmentosa is associated with mutations in more than 70 genes, and the inheritance pattern can be autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked.  Although retinitis pigmentosa can occur sporadically, the primary risk factor is family history.

Clinical presentation



The age of onset depends on the underlying genetic mutation, with most patients becoming symptomatic by early adulthood.  Symptoms are related to the loss of photoreceptors, as follows:



  • Rods allow vision in dim light, and degeneration leads to progressive night blindness.  Patients may report difficulty seeing while driving at night or difficulty acclimating to dimly lit areas.  Because rods are concentrated in the peripheral retina, degeneration of the rods also causes constriction of the visual field (ie, "tunnel vision").
  • Cones (cone photoreceptors) are most prevalent in the central retina and are affected as the disease progresses.  Degeneration leads to decreased central visual acuity and eventual blindness.


Patients may notice flashing lights (ie, photopsias) adjacent to blind spots (ie, scotomas).  The clinical manifestations of retinitis pigmentosa are typically limited to the eye, but retinitis pigmentosa can occur as part of other underlying genetic syndromes.

Diagnosis



In a patient with visual impairment concerning for retinitis pigmentosa (eg, night blindness), a comprehensive assessment of ocular functions and structures should be performed, including:



  • Peripheral vision assessment
    • Confrontation visual field testing, which is performed by asking the patient to count the examiner's fingers at each of the peripheral quadrants while fixating straight ahead.
    • Perimetry, which provides a detailed assessment of the extent of peripheral vision loss.  It is performed by asking the patient to detect brief, peripheral flashes of light while fixating in one direction.  Constricted visual fields with preservation of central vision is characteristic of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Central vision assessment
    • Visual acuity:  Retinitis pigmentosa presents with progressive peripheral vision loss, but central vision may also be affected in advanced disease.  Central vision is often evaluated using a Snellen chart to measure visual acuity (
      figure 1
      ).  A phoropter may also be used to assess for refractive errors (
      figure 2
      ), which can be associated with retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Ocular anatomy
    • Funduscopic examination:  allows a detailed examination of the retina.  Characteristic early funduscopic findings include retinal vessel attenuation (
      image 1
      ) (ie, narrow vessels likely due to alterations in retinal metabolic demand) and a waxy, pale optic disc (due to optic nerve [CN II] atrophy and gliosis).  In addition, degeneration of pigmented epithelium results in pigment deposition in a bone-spicule pattern (late finding).
    • Slit-lamp examination:  allows a microscopic view of the structures at the front and inside of the eye.  Approximately 50% of patients with retinitis pigmentosa will develop cataracts, which may be visible on slit-lamp examination.
  • Electroretinography (ERG):  utilizes a contact lens electrode to measure the electrical responses of the retina to light stimulation, providing objective evidence of retinal dysfunction.  In retinitis pigmentosa, ERG typically demonstrates reduced or absent rod and cone responses, reflecting impaired photoreceptor function.


  • Optical coherence tomography (OCT):  enables high-resolution, cross-sectional visualization of the retinal layers, allowing prompt detection of the photoreceptor layer thickness and integrity seen in retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Genetic testing:  confirms the diagnosis of retinitis pigmentosa by identifying the underlying genetic mutation.


Other assessments of visual function (eg, contrast sensitivity testing, color vision testing) may provide additional insights into visual function deficits in patients with retinitis pigmentosa.

Differential diagnosis



  • TORCH infections:  congenital Infections (eg, rubella, syphilis, toxoplasmosis) that may cause retinal pigmentary changes similar to retinitis pigmentosa.  However, the ERG would be normal or mildly abnormal in TORCH-related retinopathies.
  • Traumatic retinopathy:  months after ocular trauma, when the retinal pigment epithelium may become atrophic and release pigment, forming deposits in a characteristic bone-spicule pattern.  However, traumatic retinopathy is not progressive.


  • Vitamin A deficiency:  can cause night blindness; however, it would also cause xerophthalmia, which is characterized by excessive dryness of the cornea and conjunctiva.
  • Glaucoma (
    figure 3
    ):  may result in optic nerve atrophy and present with visual field defects and optic disc pallor.  However, retinal pigment epithelial degeneration is not expected.
  • Retinal detachment (
    figure 4
    ):  typically presents with acute vision loss along with a dark shadow (
    figure 5
    ) across the peripheral visual field, floaters, and flashes of light.  The retina has a corrugated appearance on funduscopy.
  • Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) (
    figure 6
    ):  is a degenerative disease of the photoreceptors that presents in older adults.  In contrast to retinitis pigmentosa, which presents with peripheral vision loss, AMD presents with central vision loss, and funduscopic examination reveals drusen deposition (
    image 2
    ), pigmentary changes, and geographic atrophy or choroidal neovascularization of the macula.
  • Retinal vascular diseases:  certain conditions (eg, diabetic retinopathy) that can cause retinal changes (eg, hemorrhages, exudates) and lead to visual impairment.


  • Medications (eg, chloroquine, hydroxychloroquine) and toxins (eg, methanol, ethambutol):  can cause retinal toxicity, leading to visual disturbances and characteristic retinal changes.

Management



Currently, no cure for retinitis pigmentosa exists.  Management is supportive while attempting to slow disease progression.  For example, a diet high in omega-3 fatty acids, the major lipid in photoreceptor outer membranes, is often recommended to prevent rapid degeneration.  In addition, patients may benefit from low-vision aids (eg, magnifiers, large text), orientation and mobility training, and genetic counseling.  Other treatment approaches are being developed, including gene therapy and retinal cell transplantation.

Prognosis



The prognosis of retinitis pigmentosa varies depending on the underlying genetic mutation and rate of disease progression.  Most patients are legally blind (ie, best corrected visual acuity 20/200 or worse in the better-seeing eye, field of vision â‰¤20 degrees in the better-seeing eye) by age 40.  Although the condition typically leads to blindness over time, the rate of progression can vary widely among affected individuals.

Summary



Retinitis pigmentosa is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive retinal degeneration, leading to visual impairment and potential blindness (
